JAY TRACK TEAM
BAGS SECOND WIN
Gettysburg Trackmen Lose Out
in Distance Events

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 17, 1928

STUDENTS WARNED
ABOUT PARKING
Students parking their cars
near those chains stretched
across the University roads
ate acting contrary to the rules
of the Fire Department and
the regulations of the insurance companies. The Fire Inspector has notified Sergeant
Frank that there must be no
obstructions near these chains
so that they can be removed
for the fire engines to pass
through in case of an alarm.
This is necsesary to the welfare •of both the University
and car owners.

TAG SALE FOR JUNE
WEEK TO BEGIN SOON
This Thursday Has Been Set
As Opening Date

BLUE JAY STAFF
BANQUETS APRIL 19
On Thursday, April 19, the
Blue Jay staff will hold its
annual banquet at the Southern Hotel. The original time
set for the fete was Saturday,
April 20, but this date was
moved ahead to Thursday.
The entire Jay staff is expected to participate in the
good time which is promised.
Important business relating to
next year's Jay will be carried
on at the banquet.

Subscription

The Sidney Lanier Memorial at
Johns Hopkins has received a new
impetus from the active support of
the project by Dr. Edwin Greenlaw, Osler Professor df English
Literature in this University. Himself a generous contributor to the
Lanier fund, Dr. Greenlaw urges
that the few thousand dollars now
in hand be increased to a sum adequate to endow a Sidney Lanier
professorship of American Literature at Johns Hopkins. For this
purpose, he points out, an endowment of $200,000 is necessary. Of
this the income of $150,000 should
provide the salary of the professor.
From the income of the remaining
portion of the endowment provision
should be made for a Sidney Lanier
Fellowship in American Literature,
for a scholarship or lectureship, and
for the purchase of books, periodicals and other materials of research.

CONTEST AT ASSEMBLY

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Queens College in Canada was
the scene of some recent unpleasantness between the student body
and the faculty of that institution.
When five undergraduates were suspended a short time ago—two for
drinking and three for holding an
objectionable social affair—the governing body, which handed down
the decision, was greeted by an uproar of protest and expressions of
dissatisfaction. All attempts at
mediation failing, group by group
of the undergraduates agreed to
walk out, and thus to definitely signify their protest. With this action
staring them in the face, the faculty was forced to capitulate on the
following day by reinstating the
suspended students and by granting
attendance to the strikers for all
classes missed during their selfimposed holiday.
*

*

*

*

*

Lack of enforcement of freshman
regulations at Boston Tech is being
considered seriously by the undergraduates. Numerous remedies have
been suggested, but it has finally
been decided to publish the names
of all frosh offenders in the student
paper in the hope that the added
publicity will bring about a little
deliberation on the part of the delinquents. We wonder what accounts for a lack of similar feeling
here at Hopkins, where the decadence of the freshman regulations
has been greeted only by indifference.

College students are not strictly
honest. At least one might so judge
by the slight example furnished by
the undergraduates at Northwestern.
The candy stands at that institution,
operated on the honor system, were
recently subjected to an inventory,
as a result of which it was discovered that there was approximately
$600 unaccounted for since the beginning of the scholastic year. Everything from slugs and street car
tokens to German marks have been
-utilized by the enterprising student
body.

Using the following figures as a
basis, how does our situation as
undergraduates at Hopkins compare? The average cost of one
year's so-called education at Cornell
is $1,410, according to the statistics
of the university authorities. The
fraternity member spends approximately $1,420 per annum; whereas,
to the surprise of the critics of modern fraternity life, the non-fraternity man expends nearly the same
sum, an average of $1,398. The
expenses of the fair co-ed who has
indulged in a sorority amounts to

Charleston, W. Va.,
March 4, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.,
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
Recently i stopped in a little village
that consisted of about nine houses
and a small hotel, which I entered.
A little old man wearing a skull cap
was seated in a rocking-chair smoking
an enormous pipe. I had come to buy
a can of Edgeworth,but when I caughL
a whiff of the tobacco he was smoking
I changed my mind. The aroma of
that tobacco was so delightful that I
made up my mind right then and there
that I wanted some of the same brand,
regardless of the cost.
I began with: "I beg your pardon,
sir, but I came in to buy a can of tobacco,and I would like the same brand
you are smoking if you don't mind
telling me." He looked at me for a
moment, grasped his pipe with one
hand and said: "I'm smoking Edgeworth. Would you like some?"
Of course I did, and I secured a
supply from the old fellow. The joke,
of course, was on me, but I went on
my way rejoicing.
Yours very truly,
Dr. John R. Koch

their similarity to their fellows at
Hopkins or indeed at any other university. The five subjects are, of
course, professors, college, religion,
fraternities, and sex. It's a small
old world after all.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1928

6

LACROSSE TEAM OPENS
SEASON WITH WIN
Regulars Pile Up Big Lead in
First Half; Score 12-1
Hopkins won its first victory of
the 1928 lacrosse season at the expense of Virginia on Saturday,
April 7, by a score of 12-1. The
powerful Jay attack piled up a big
lead early in the game, and the substitutes soon began to enter the contest. Ben Eagan scored the first
goal of the year with a shot from
the front of the goal before the first
minute had elapsed. Biddison rang
the bell next, after receiving a long
pass from Logan. The whirlwind
attack of the Jays threw the ball in
the netting seven times before the
substitutes were sent in.

Wallace to Address
Debating Councils
Tudor-Stuart Club
Schedule Announced
Dr. Malcolm W. Wallace will be
the annual speaker for the Tudor
and Stuart Club on April 20 at five
o'clock. The subject of Dr. Wallace's address will be "The Reputation of Sir Philip Sidney."
Dr. Wallace, who is at present
the professor of English in the
University of Toronto, is the greatest living authority on Sir Philip
Sidney. His talk will be in keeping
with the literary period in which
the Tudor and Stuart Club is especially interested.
After the lecture a banquet will
be held in Alumini Memorial Hall
at seven-thirty.

BLUE JAY STAFF
BANQUETS APRIL 19
On Thursday, April 19, the
Blue Jay staff will hold its
annual banquet at the Southern Hotel. The original time
set for the fete was Saturday,
April 20, but this date was
moved ahead to Thursday.
The entire Jay staff is expected to participate in the
good time which is promised.
Important business relating to
next year's Jay will be carried
on at the banquet.

Subscription

The Sidney Lanier Memorial at
Johns Hopkins has received a new
impetus from the active support of
the project by Dr. Edwin Greenlaw, Osler Professor df English
Literature in this University. Himself a generous contributor to the
Lanier fund, Dr. Greenlaw urges
that the few thousand dollars now
in hand be increased to a sum adequate to endow a Sidney Lanier
professorship of American Literature at Johns Hopkins. For this
purpose, he points out, an endowment of $200,000 is necessary. Of
this the income of $150,000 should
provide the salary of the professor.
From the income of the remaining
portion of the endowment provision
should be made for a Sidney Lanier
Fellowship in American Literature,
for a scholarship or lectureship, and
for the purchase of books, periodicals and other materials of research.

Friday, the thirteenth, had a surprise in store for the Hopkins and
Washington and Lee debaters. Upon
the arrival of the latter at the Civil
Engineering Hall Friday night, it
was found that the two teams had
prepared themselves on entirely different subjects.
Washington and Lee agreed to
debate a subject similar to that prepared by Hopkins: "Resolved, that
the United States should cease to
protect by armed force, except after
fromal declaration of war, capital
invested in foreign lands." The
affirmative argument was delivered

CONTEST AT ASSEMBLY

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Queens College in Canada was
the scene of some recent unpleasantness between the student body
and the faculty of that institution.
When five undergraduates were suspended a short time ago—two for
drinking and three for holding an
objectionable social affair—the governing body, which handed down
the decision, was greeted by an uproar of protest and expressions of
dissatisfaction. All attempts at
mediation failing, group by group
of the undergraduates agreed to
walk out, and thus to definitely signify their protest. With this action
staring them in the face, the faculty was forced to capitulate on the
following day by reinstating the
suspended students and by granting
attendance to the strikers for all
classes missed during their selfimposed holiday.
*

*

*

*

*

Lack of enforcement of freshman
regulations at Boston Tech is being
considered seriously by the undergraduates. Numerous remedies have
been suggested, but it has finally
been decided to publish the names
of all frosh offenders in the student
paper in the hope that the added
publicity will bring about a little
deliberation on the part of the delinquents. We wonder what accounts for a lack of similar feeling
here at Hopkins, where the decadence of the freshman regulations
has been greeted only by indifference.

College students are not strictly
honest. At least one might so judge
by the slight example furnished by
the undergraduates at Northwestern.
The candy stands at that institution,
operated on the honor system, were
recently subjected to an inventory,
as a result of which it was discovered that there was approximately
$600 unaccounted for since the beginning of the scholastic year. Everything from slugs and street car
tokens to German marks have been
-utilized by the enterprising student
body.

Using the following figures as a
basis, how does our situation as
undergraduates at Hopkins compare? The average cost of one
year's so-called education at Cornell
is $1,410, according to the statistics
of the university authorities. The
fraternity member spends approximately $1,420 per annum; whereas,
to the surprise of the critics of modern fraternity life, the non-fraternity man expends nearly the same
sum, an average of $1,398. The
expenses of the fair co-ed who has
indulged in a sorority amounts to

Charleston, W. Va.,
March 4, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.,
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
Recently i stopped in a little village
that consisted of about nine houses
and a small hotel, which I entered.
A little old man wearing a skull cap
was seated in a rocking-chair smoking
an enormous pipe. I had come to buy
a can of Edgeworth,but when I caughL
a whiff of the tobacco he was smoking
I changed my mind. The aroma of
that tobacco was so delightful that I
made up my mind right then and there
that I wanted some of the same brand,
regardless of the cost.
I began with: "I beg your pardon,
sir, but I came in to buy a can of tobacco,and I would like the same brand
you are smoking if you don't mind
telling me." He looked at me for a
moment, grasped his pipe with one
hand and said: "I'm smoking Edgeworth. Would you like some?"
Of course I did, and I secured a
supply from the old fellow. The joke,
of course, was on me, but I went on
my way rejoicing.
Yours very truly,
Dr. John R. Koch

That ancient and honorable collegiate institution familiarly known as
the "bull session" has at last resulted in the publication of a magazine at California which is entitled
the Bull Fest. The material is said
to have been gathered from a series
of sessions attended by fraternity
brothers, outsiders and a nightwatchman. Five subjects are concerned, of which one need say no
more, if in this respect only, undergraduates at California have shown
their similarity to their fellows at
Hopkins or indeed at any other university. The five subjects are, of
course, professors, college, religion,
fraternities, and sex. It's a small
old world after all.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 17, 1928

6

LACROSSE TEAM OPENS
SEASON WITH WIN
Regulars Pile Up Big Lead in
First Half; Score 12-1
Hopkins won its first victory of
the 1928 lacrosse season at the expense of Virginia on Saturday,
April 7, by a score of 12-1. The
powerful Jay attack piled up a big
lead early in the game, and the substitutes soon began to enter the contest. Ben Eagan scored the first
goal of the year with a shot from
the front of the goal before the first
minute had elapsed. Biddison rang
the bell next, after receiving a long
pass from Logan. The whirlwind
attack of the Jays threw the ball in
the netting seven times before the
substitutes were sent in.

Wallace to Address
Debating Councils
Tudor-Stuart Club
Schedule Announced
Dr. Malcolm W. Wallace will be
the annual speaker for the Tudor
and Stuart Club on April 20 at five
o'clock. The subject of Dr. Wallace's address will be "The Reputation of Sir Philip Sidney."
Dr. Wallace, who is at present
the professor of English in the
University of Toronto, is the greatest living authority on Sir Philip
Sidney. His talk will be in keeping
with the literary period in which
the Tudor and Stuart Club is especially interested.
After the lecture a banquet will
be held in Alumini Memorial Hall
at seven-thirty.
